content.description: Alternate start to lost corner. The alternate start makes the first section probably 5.6 and 10-15 feet shorter.
content.protection: There are a few trees 50 feet away that could be used for a top rope anchor. I looped webbing around 2 protrusions of rock and stuck a cam in a crack to make an anchor to TR.
content.location: Start at the crack just right of the chimney to begin letterbox instead of the off-width around the corner.

content.description:
Lost Corner and Crossover share the same first 50 foot section.  Follow the large-hand crack to a small ledge with some loose rocks.  A smaller crack parallels on the left.  Trickier than it looks. 

  From the ledge you have a couple of choices...
content.protection: Very large cams are very welcome in the first section.  A large chockstone can be slung halfway up.  Suitable trees for anchors are found a little way from the edge.  A 60 meter rope is fine, but knot the ends if you rapp.
content.location: Small left-facing corner to the left a bigger left-facing corner (Downcast).  Rapp down (not easy to spot) or scramble down the descent trail from the blue trail and work your way climber's right about 75 feet.

content.description: The route starts up the wide chimney formed by the massive blocks.  Once on the ledge midway you can climb a slimmer chimney with two laser cracks in the back or a hand crack to the right of the chimney.  The bottom is super fun.  It's like a giant jungle gym swinging your way up between the massive blocks.
content.protection: Protection down low is a bit sparse but good.  The chimney and crack after the ledge are laser split and take gear the whole way.  Nice trees up top for anchors
content.location: The route is at the very left of the Dihedral Section.  Look for the massive blocks separated from the cliff.  Rap off the trees up above or seek out one of the gullies nearby.

climbs.name: Journey to the Scenter of the Earth (note the spelling of "Scenter")
climbs.fa: FA: Nichols, Bruce Bates 11/74 FA present route: Jim Adair, Bruce Dicks 10/77

content.description: Crux is the second ceiling, 5.10, the rest of the route is probably 5.7-5.8 except the first 10 feet which is closer to 5.5.Â
content.protection: Trees suitable to top rope at the top, but falling before you get through the second ceiling can produce a significant swing out away from the wall.

content.description:
The climb has two sections.  The first 50 foot section is a nice large-hand crack in a left-facing corner.  A smaller crack parallels on the left.  You'll then reach a ledge with small trees. 

  The second 40 foot section...
content.protection: Large cams are very welcome in the first section. Suitable trees for anchors are at the top.
content.location: Look for the largest left-facing corner.  You'll notice that the ground drops off very steeply to the right of the corner and you'll see a couple of chimneys/roof systems (Black Clound and Journey to the Center of the Earth) to the right.

content.description: Same start as Lost Corner but when you reach the ledge follow it right to the base of the dihedral with a thin crack (Downcast) and follow the wider somewhat blocky crack to the right.  The crux is just before you reach the ledge above the first section. The good stuff is the beginning of the climb.
content.protection: Good gear the whole way.  Standard rack.  A couple trees up top for anchors.
content.location: The first dihedral corner system to the right of Letterbox

content.description: The climbs in this area are about 100 ft long and separated into two sections by a ledge.  It is relatively shady and cool for East Peak.  The goat trail along the base of the climbs is sketchy and loose.
